'''''Lenzites elegans''''' – also known as ''Trametes elegans'' and ''Daedalea elegans'' – is a common [[polypore]] and [[wood-decay fungus]] with a [[pantropical]] distribution, found on hardwood hosts in regions including eastern North America, Australia, New Zealand, and Japan.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nt.ars-grin.gov/fungaldatabases/new_allView.cfm?whichone=all&thisName=Trametes%20elegans&organismtype=Fungus&fromAllCount=yes|title=Trametes elegans|last=Farr|first=D.F.|last2=Rossman|first2=A.Y.|date=|website=Fungal Databases, [[U.S. National Fungus Collections]], [[Agricultural Research Service|ARS]], [[USDA]]|archive-url=https://archive.is/TiZtN|archive-date=20 November 2018|dead-url=|access-date=20 November 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nt.ars-grin.gov/fungaldatabases/new_allView.cfm?whichone=all&thisName=Lenzites%20elegans&organismtype=Fungus&fromAllCount=yes|title=Lenzites elegans|last=Farr|first=D.F.|last2=Rossman|first2=A.Y.|date=|website=Fungal Databases, [[U.S. National Fungus Collections]], [[Agricultural Research Service|ARS]], [[USDA]]|archive-url=http://archive.fo/MrzgV|archive-date=20 November 2018|dead-url=|access-date=20 November 2018}}</ref> Alluding to the pore surface which often exhibits a maze-like structure,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mushroomexpert.com/trametes_elegans.html|title=Trametes elegans|last=Kuo|first=Michael|date=March 2005|website=MushroomExpert.Com|archive-url=https://archive.is/1jM1T|archive-date=20 November 2018|dead-url=|access-date=20 November 2018}}</ref> ''L. elegans'' is also referred to as '''white maze polypore'''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inaturalist.org/taxa/128053-Trametes-elegans|title=white maze polypore (Trametes elegans)|website=iNaturalist.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-21}}</ref>
